paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does TRAPPIST-1 b retain an atmosphere under strong stellar irradiation from its M dwarf host, and what constraints do JWST MIRI phase-curve observations provide on atmospheric composition and heat redistribution?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: TRAPPIST-1 b Phase-Curve Observations
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy over complete orbital phase curve
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Thermal phase variation and spectral structure observations around the 15 um CO2 band for TRAPPIST-1 b using JWST MIRI instrument

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Bare-Rock No-Atmosphere Model
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Theoretical model assuming no atmosphere with minimal heat redistribution, representing a bare rocky surface that immediately reradiates absorbed stellar energy

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-Rich Atmosphere Scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmospheric model incorporating significant greenhouse gas absorption from CO2, testing whether observed spectral features match predicted signatures

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-Rich Atmosphere Scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmospheric model assuming oxidized composition with different spectral properties, providing alternative composition constraints

major_limitations: This is a single-planet study and does not establish atmospheric prevalence across all M-dwarf rocky planets
Retrieval assumptions including circulation patterns, opacity priors, and cloud treatment affect quantitative posteriors
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias interpretation of weak spectral features
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset due to observation geometry
